qas.question: What is the time limit for designating a species critical habitat after the species has been added to the endangered list?
Which presidential adminstration limited the protective status of critical habitat in 1986?
After the limitations placed on critical habitat were lifted by the courts, where were critical habitats established primarily?

answers.text: Hawaii, California and other western states

qas.question: Where have the majority of critical habitats in the Midwest and Eastern states been located geographically?
What has to be designated after a waiting period of 1 year?
What entity caused an increase of critical habitats in between 1986 and the 1990s?
What did the Reagan regulations invalidate?
How many critical habitats were built between 1978 and 1986?
Which two states in the Midwest and Eastern states received fewer habitats?

context: The ESA requires that <b4_0>critical habitat<b4_0/> be designated at the time of or <a0_0>within one year<a0_0/> of a species being placed on the endangered list. In practice, most designations occur several years after listing. Between 1978 and 1986 the FWS regularly designated critical habitat. In 1986 <a1_0><b5_0>the Reagan Administration<b5_0/><a1_0/> issued a regulation limiting the protective status of critical habitat. As a result, few critical habitats were designated between 1986 and the late 1990s. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, <b6_0>a series of court orders<b6_0/> invalidated the Reagan regulations and forced the FWS and NMFS to designate <b7_0>several hundred<b7_0/> critical habitats, especially in <a2_0><b8_0>Hawaii, California<b8_0/> and other western states<a2_0/>. Midwest and Eastern states received less critical habitat, <a3_0>primarily on rivers and coastlines<a3_0/>. As of December, 2006, the Reagan regulation has not yet been replaced though its use has been suspended. Nonetheless, the agencies have generally changed course and since about 2005 have tried to designate critical habitat at or near the time of listing.
